description: From Middle English prodige (“portent”), from Latin prōdigium (“omen, portent, prophetic sign”).

entries.meaning: (now rare) An extraordinary thing seen as an omen; a portent. [from 15th c.]
examples: John Foxe believed that special prodigies had heralded the Reformation.

entries.meaning: An extraordinary occurrence or creature; an anomaly, especially a monster; a freak. [from 16th c.]
An amazing or marvellous thing; a wonder. [from 17th c.]
A wonderful example of something. [from 17th c.]
An extremely talented person, especially a child. [from 17th c.]
